ayahs.text:
This verse poses a rhetorical question asking whether Allah has not expanded and opened the chest of His Messenger, indicating the divine gift of spiritual expansion and inner peace. The expansion of the chest represents the removal of anxiety and distress, replacing it with tranquility, steadiness, and spiritual capacity to bear the responsibilities of prophethood.

This expansion involves the pouring of oceans of knowledge and understanding into the heart, along with the granting of vast patience and endurance necessary to fulfill the duties of messengership. The spiritual expansion enables the soul to contain divine wisdom and bear the weight of delivering divine guidance to humanity, transforming inner constriction into boundless spiritual capacity and peace.

The verse speaks of removing the burden that was weighing heavily upon the Messenger's back. This burden represents the spiritual and psychological weight that comes from the contrast between experiencing divine proximity and having to engage with the world to fulfill the mission of guidance.

The burden specifically refers to the difficulty experienced when transitioning from states of spiritual elevation and divine closeness to the challenges of dealing with people's rejection, mockery, and opposition. This weight on the soul comes from having to leave the blissful states of divine communion to face the harsh realities of conveying the message to those who resist or ridicule divine guidance.

This verse declares that Allah has elevated and honored the mention and remembrance of His Messenger. This elevation refers to how the name and message of the Prophet have been raised to the highest status and made honorable throughout the world and for all time.

The elevation of mention encompasses both the respect accorded to the Messenger's name and the widespread acceptance and transmission of his message. This honor extends beyond temporal recognition to include eternal remembrance and reverence, where the mention of the Prophet's name becomes a source of blessing and spiritual elevation for those who remember him with respect and love.

The verse establishes the fundamental principle that with every difficulty comes ease and relief. This represents one of the most important spiritual laws governing human experience, where hardships are always accompanied by divine mercy and assistance that make the difficulties bearable and ultimately beneficial.

This principle applies universally to all believers and represents divine wisdom in the structure of human experience. Every challenge contains within it the seeds of its own resolution, and every trial brings with it divine support and eventual relief. This understanding provides hope during difficult times and confidence that no hardship is permanent or without purpose in the divine plan.

This verse repeats the same principle as the previous verse, emphasizing through repetition that indeed, with hardship comes ease. The repetition serves to reinforce this fundamental truth and provide additional assurance and comfort to those facing difficulties.

The emphasis through repetition indicates that this is not merely a temporary consolation but a permanent spiritual law that governs the relationship between difficulty and divine relief. The duplication of this statement strengthens faith during challenging times and reminds believers that divine assistance is certain and that every period of hardship will inevitably be followed by periods of ease and comfort.

Reiterating the divine principle, this verse again confirms that verily, with difficulty comes ease. The triple repetition of this fundamental truth emphasizes its absolute certainty and its central importance in understanding how divine mercy operates in human affairs.

This repeated affirmation serves to embed this principle deeply in the consciousness of believers, ensuring that during times of trial, they remember this divine promise with complete confidence. The consistency of this message throughout these verses demonstrates that relief from hardship is not an exception but a fundamental characteristic of how Allah deals with those who are struggling in His path.

This verse provides instruction for when one becomes free from the duties and obligations of prophethood, directing to continue striving and exerting effort. The instruction indicates that even after completing major responsibilities, the believer should not rest but should channel their energy into continued spiritual effort and service.

The command to continue striving after completion of duties represents the principle that spiritual development and service to Allah are continuous endeavors that do not end with the completion of specific tasks. This instruction emphasizes that freedom from one set of obligations should lead to engagement in even higher forms of worship and spiritual devotion rather than to idleness or complacency.

The final verse instructs to turn with complete attention and desire toward Allah when freed from worldly duties. This represents the ultimate goal of spiritual life - to reach a state where one can focus entirely on divine connection without the distractions of worldly obligations and responsibilities.

This instruction parallels the message found in Surah An-Nasr, where after the completion of the prophetic mission and the victory of Islam, the focus shifts entirely to divine remembrance and seeking closeness to Allah. It represents the natural progression from serving Allah through serving humanity to serving Allah through direct spiritual communion and devotion, marking the completion of worldly mission and the beginning of purely spiritual journey.
